title: Chord Construction
description: Learn how triads are built from intervals — major, minor, diminished, and augmented.

steps.title: Building Blocks of Chords
steps.description:
A triad is a three-note chord built by stacking two intervals of a 3rd:

• Major triad: Major 3rd + Minor 3rd (4 + 3 semitones)
• Minor triad: Minor 3rd + Major 3rd (3 + 4 semitones)
• Diminished triad: Minor 3rd + Minor 3rd (3 + 3 semitones)
• Augmented triad: Major 3rd + Major 3rd (4 + 4 semitones)

steps.title: Build C Major (4+3)
steps.description: C major = C + E (4 semitones) + G (3 more semitones). Major 3rd on bottom, minor 3rd on top.

steps.title: Build C Minor (3+4)
steps.description: C minor = C + Eb (3 semitones) + G (4 more semitones). The intervals are reversed from major!

steps.title: Build B Diminished (3+3)
steps.description: B diminished = B + D (3 semitones) + F (3 more semitones). Two minor 3rds stacked. Tense and unstable.

steps.title: Build C Augmented (4+4)
steps.description: C augmented = C + E (4 semitones) + G# (4 more semitones). Two major 3rds. Mysterious and dreamy.

steps.title: A Simple Way to Remember
steps.description:
Think of it as stacking 3rds:

• Major: big + small (happy)
• Minor: small + big (sad)
• Diminished: small + small (tense)
• Augmented: big + big (dreamy)

The total size of the chord (root to 5th) tells you the quality: 7 semitones = perfect, 6 = diminished, 8 = augmented.
